narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Really opened my eyes to the deep and rich Caribbean history that is often overlooked in most history classes revolving around the United States. Topics included early imperialism, transatlantic slavery, plantation capitalism, slavery and abolition, and post-abolition Caribbean governments. Very interesting discussions around the Haitian and Cuban Revolutions. I'll also never misspell 'Caribbean' again.
I learned a general history of the Caribbean and about patterns of colonialism, resistance, imperialism, and fights for sovereignty.
I gained both an understanding of the big picture and more specific patterns of Caribbean history, especially when it comes to the lasting effects of colonization and the consequential resistance.
I found that this course helped me gain a general introduction to Caribbean history and to read history papers from a more historiographic perspective.
I learned so much about early and modern Caribbean history. I think this class is a great intro course and it lays down the foundation for an interest in more nuanced topics.
Helpful way to understand how Caribbean history progressed and thus how to understand the politics and culture of the contemporary caribbean

From native settlement through modern-day history I gained a comprehensive and critical understanding of Caribbean History. This was my first introduction to global history and the lens provided through the Caribbean was incredibly instructive. Our content began with early colonialism and encounters with native populations on the island nations, the trans-Atlantic slave trade and the development of the plantation economy. From the beginning, narratives of oppression were countered consistently by narratives of "counter-plantation" forces, tactics, and strategies. Always, the analyses were attuned to the role of gender and archive in altering history. We learned about the system of apprenticeship, early revolutions, nationalism, colonialism and neocolonialism.
Reading response assignments facilitated the skills to write strong claims and structure convincing arguments. The final essay introduced students to incorporating primary sources.
I gained a deeper insight into the harshness of Caribbean plantation life, as well as an understanding on how racial bias affects certain aspects of our curriculum.
I learned a great amount of Caribbean history, especially regarding Caribbean trade, slavery and indenture, the Haitian Revolution, and the Cuban Revolution.
I learned about the basics of Caribbean history and how the region has changed through the lenses of revolution and cultural change
Developed a foundational understanding of the history of the Caribbean
amazing understanding of Caribbean history along with its recurring themes
We learned how to better engage with the sources used by historical texts and bring critiques and arguments about their analysis rather than the content itself, an important distinction in history.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: readings typically interesting, relatively low work (Three 3-page pagers, a midterm, and final paper that's just an extension of one of the papers you already wrote), awesome TAs and Prof. Eller is great.

Weaknesses: one week we had to read a 300+ page memoir, but that was the only assignment where the reading was unnecessarily long; Prof. Eller talks pretty fast and touches on a bunch of different topics, sometimes straying away from main point of the lecture;

strengths: Prof. Eller is so knowledgeable and passionate about her field of study, easy writing credit, INCREDIBLE readings; weaknesses: heavy reading some weeks, little interaction with students on Zoom lectures when everyone's muted with cameras off

Professor Eller is incredibly knowledgeable and engaging, and her enthusiasm for the subject at hand is infectious. The readings, much of it drawn from recent scholarship, were generally quite interesting. However, I found myself wishing that the class was a seminar rather than a lecture, as Professor Eller's personable teaching style practically invited questions and critical discussion, neither of which we had time for when class was only 50 minutes long and the material was so broad. I felt that the classes might have felt more like (and been more effective as) lectures if they were more goal oriented or began/ended with a summary of key points and essential vocab, which would have made it easier to structure notes and retain information.

Professor Eller's enthusiasm for the material makes the course more engaging, and the well-thought-out structure of the course makes it so we gain both breadth and depth of Caribbean history. Most importantly, the course was refreshing as far as history courses go in that it did not shy away from acknowledging the ways the US itself has been a harmful force in Caribbean history, and makes an effort to center Caribbean resistance rather than focus on only imperial growth.

The course felt kind of a mess. The work load in terms of reading was quite high but did not well supplement the lectureseither they felt repetitive or totally disjoint. The grading was harsh but the feedback was unclear. In addition, the lecture style felt unfocused to me and was sometimes difficult to follow.
Anne is amazing. I really have no other commentary.
Excellent TA (Emily Snyder)

Strengths are the dynamism of Professor Eller's lectures, the unique research contributions and diligent commitment of the Teaching Fellows. Lectures were always fast-paced and engaging. In a Zoom setting, where it is easy to tune out of class, I would practice as many strong habits to stay focused in Prof Eller's lectures. If you stop listening for even a second, you may miss a lyrical insight or witty joke. The course facilitated a community (even online!) between TFs, students and professor by inviting and engaging with guest lectures, sharing each TF's research and always being attuned to the needs of online learning, the COVID pandemic, and the national election.
Weaknesses are also found in the dynamic, fast-paced lectures. Professor Eller is incredibly well read. At times her tangents would veer into material that students were unfamiliar with and therefore unable to engage with. A stronger organization of the main lecture and perhaps reserving a few moments at the end of lecture for tangents, might be beneficial, especially for students new to the field.

Strength  a good survey of Caribbean history from 1400 to present day. 

Weakness  it's a ton, ton of content, obviously. There were many great threads and tidbits that were briefly touched on in lectures and readings that were never picked up on again. I don't think you can really trim much fat from this course, either, which presents a problem. 

Improvement: 
Split the course into fall & spring courses. A good model would be Merriman's French history courses (one goes from the late 1700s till the late 1800s, and the following course picks right up until present day). A fantastic course would be a Caribbean history course from 1400 to the Haitian Revolution, followed by a course from the Haitian Revolution to present day.

I really enjoyed the live discussion sections as opportunities to further discuss topics covered in lecture. I would have appreciated a bit more structure with the lecture material to help with reviewing for the midterm, but the lectures were really interesting, nonetheless.
Excellent material and pace, I would not change much

strengths: incredibly interesting material
weaknesses: lectures were sometimes disorganized and there was minimal material on the slides; very difficult to understand some of the week's material by looking at the slides alone - important to attend or listen to lecture

Professor Eller just kind of started talking every lecture and it didn't feel like there was much direction, so it was hard for someone with very little knowledge of caribbean history to follow, even from the beginning

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Recorded lectures were essential when studying for midterms; I don't know what I would have done if I didn't have access to those videos while studying.
The workload was manageable and there was flexibility with assignment due dates which I appreciated.
The recorded lectures were a great resource!
The class successfully transitioned to online and that did not seem to impact it much.
N/A

Professor Eller and the TFs were transparent and proactive in acknowledging the technical and interpersonal difficulties of online learning during a pandemic, national election and many other personal crises. Their communication and actively welcoming personalities contributed most to the strong online learning environment.
The office hour system worked well for remote learning. There is nothing that needs to be improved for this class.
I really appreciated the recorded lectures and midterm and final formats. I thought the assignments were well geared towards the unpredictable timing that came with online learning!
The live virtual lectures, live virtual discussion sections, the writing assignments, and the online readings were all appropriate for the pandemic situation.
Live lectures were appreciated and helped with engagement
Flexible, self-paced paper-writing schedule and lots of availability for office hours were very helpful.

I really appreciated that we got slides ahead of time to view on our own, during and after lectures, so if I missed something we had gone over I could look back and fill in the information if it was on the slides. That said, I appreciate that they were so visual but I wonder if some more written information/details might've been helpful for this purpose (names, dates, vocabulary terms, etc.).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. Low work, WR credit, learned a lot, great Prof. and TAs
Yes! Everyone should be required to learn about Caribbean history. The syllabus is amazing.

YES! Anyone remotely interested in history, the Caribbean, Latin-America, or even with a desire to have a fully informed opinion of Western powers and how they're historically abused certain regions should take this class.
No I would not. Although the content was interesting, I did not feel that it was presented in a way conducive to learning.
Yes! You will learn a lot. Anne is a refreshing lecturer and really knows her stuff.
Yes it was a fantastic class

I would recommend this course to students especially to students who don't think the Caribbean or its history may be particularly relevant to their field of study in the humanities. The Caribbean is a unique historical and contemporary site for the entanglement of so much of human history, economy and society. Anyone interested in history, language, diaspora--no matter if of a different geographic specificity--will gain tremendously from the transnational and decolonial frameworks of this course. The assignments are easy, the readings and lectures are very engaging (virtually too!) and the learning environment is tremendously supportive.
Yes
Yes!!!

Yes. Professor Eller is very kind & so are the TAs. The content is interesting, something worthy of more study, and something you probably aren't super familiar with. It's a great bird's eye view of the history or the Caribbean, and you can't ask for much more from a class spanning so much time and space. The midterm is very very fair, and the papers are flexible and you get to write about what you're interested in. If you want to learn more about the Caribbean, take it. If you need a LatAm history credit, take it. If you need a WR credit that's both interesting & not too difficult, take it. If you want a broad intro to ER&M concepts, take it.
Yes; it opens up a new insight into slavery across the Caribbean, particularly from a slave point of view.
Yes! Professor Eller is a great lecturer and the topics covered in this class were extremely important and deserve more attention in our history curriculums!
Yes, the course is great for history majors and non-history majors alike. No prior knowledge of Caribbean history is expected, and you still learn a lot.
Yes; the Caribbean is often overlooked in the study of history and this course gives a great starting point.
Absolutely! Definitely take this class, it is so important.
Anne Eller is one of Yale's few gems, I absolutely recommend taking any course with her!
Easy writing credit, but not facilitated for learning well

Yes, 1000%, especially for students in social sciences but not limited to just them. The Caribbean is the birthplace of the social orders and economic systems we have today and understanding the history of this region helps one understand the socio-economic systems that we are all subject to today. The readings were also magnificent because they were full of information and incredible history. This class is a must take.
